attachments.title: How The Great French Wine Blight Changed Grapes Forever
attachments.text: One hundred fifty years ago, the Great French Wine Blight nearly wiped out an industry that today produces some 40 billion bottles of wine a year. The only solution was a radical fusion of species that remains essential to the success of the wine market. Here's the story of how humanity hacked the wine grape.
attachments.fallback: io9: How The Great French Wine Blight Changed Grapes Forever

text: <@U02F8LF2X|chewbacca> uploaded a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/chewbacca/F042FLW4Z/_dsc6242.jpg|_DSC6242.jpg>
here are the two boards reflowed. note that there are some components on the back of the RF one that either need to be populated by hand or I need to start developing my two-sided reflow technique.
how the heck do you do two-sided reflow?
3d-print a mold to hold the lower components in place?
very carefully?
I think you apply solder paste to the pads and then put the world's smallest drop of super glue beneath each component?
I'm not sure though; never done it
ooh, that would work too

On the line in Hawthorne Farms, we'd  flow one side, flip and flow the other. The board is held by the edges in the oven (thus the placement keepouts all around), and the bottom-side components are held in place by the surface tension of the solder. Generally speaking, our placement rules dictated only discretes on the back of the board to minimize the chance parts will fall off. We made exceptions for TQFPs and BGAs that had high pin-count because there was more than enough contact to hold them there.
The only other gotcha is that resistors and caps could "tombstone" if they weren't securely pasted down since one side's surface tension could grab it before the other pad did.
hum ok. maybe I'll give it a whirl
can you tell me more about how it's held at the edges?
Been a while, but as I recall it's a set of corners and edge holders that are L shaped that can adjust to the size of the board. Board rests on those. For mass-production, it's a custom ring.
My layout adheres to OSHPark's specs, but they're for hand-solder, not conveyor reflow
I'd say flow the back side first (Atmel chip, crystal and resistors) then the radio side since the pushbutton and antenna connector are likely to fall off
alternately, you could do the top first, flip and use the heat gun to flow the Atmel etc
would work great, I'm thinking, and pretty easy
could hold it in the vise by the edges
need one of those swedish waffle irons
ok well I'll think about it tomorrow. those stupid taco holders will be printing all day so I won't be distracted by 3d printing for a change
hahaha
